message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and history suggest the diagnosis of Boerhaave syndrome, which is a spontaneous rupture of the esophagus due to forceful vomiting. The crunching, raspy sound auscultated on cardiac examination is known as Hamman sign. The contrast esophagram is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis. Upper endoscopy may miss the diagnosis and can worsen the rupture while D-dimer is not relevant to this diagnosis. ECG may show changes due to stress from the patient’s condition, but it is not specific for Boerhaave syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest esophageal rupture, specifically Boerhaave syndrome, which is a medical emergency. The most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis is a contrast esophagram. Upper endoscopy may be used to visualize the esophagus but is not as sensitive as a contrast study. ECG and measurement of D-dimer are not useful in diagnosing esophageal rupture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest Boerhaave syndrome, which is a rupture of the esophagus caused by forceful vomiting. A contrast esophagram can confirm the diagnosis by showing contrast extravasation into the mediastinum. Upper endoscopy may also be used to visualize the esophagus but may be more invasive. ECG and D-dimer are not relevant in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the chest pain, crunching sound on cardiac examination, and history of self-induced vomiting suggest that the patient has Boerhaave syndrome, which is a rupture of the esophageal wall due to forceful vomiting. The most appropriate test to confirm diagnosis would be a contrast esophagram, which can show extravasation of contrast from the esophageal lumen into the mediastinum. Upper endoscopy would not be appropriate in this case as it may worsen the condition, and ECG and D-dimer tests are not relevant to this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden chest pain and crunching sound over the precordium suggest a diagnosis of Boerhaave syndrome or esophageal rupture after vomiting. Upper endoscopy and ECG may help rule out other causes of chest pain, but a contrast esophagram is the diagnostic test of choice to confirm esophageal rupture. Measurement of D-dimer is not relevant in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including severe retrosternal chest pain, self-induced vomiting, and restricted food intake, suggest esophageal rupture or Boerhaave syndrome. The crunching, raspy sound over the precordium that is synchronous with the heartbeat is called Hamman's sign, which is indicative of mediastinal emphysema. A contrast esophagram is the best test to confirm the diagnosis. Upper endoscopy may be used to visualize the esophagus, but it carries the risk of perforation. ECG and D-dimer are not useful in diagnosing esophageal rupture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical examination suggest Boerhaave syndrome, which is a rupture of the esophagus following forceful vomiting. The crunching, raspy sound on cardiac examination is called Hamman's sign, which is pathognomonic for this condition. A contrast esophagram is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis. Upper endoscopy may be used to evaluate the extent of the injury, but it is not the best initial test. ECG and measurement of D-dimer are not helpful in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the patient’s history and symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is Boerhaave syndrome, which is a spontaneous rupture of the esophagus due to forceful vomiting. A contrast esophagram can reveal extravasation of contrast material into the mediastinum or pleural space, confirming the diagnosis. Upper endoscopy or ECG may show nonspecific findings, and measurement of D-dimer is not indicated in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the patient might have Boerhaave syndrome, which is a tear or rupture of the esophagus due to forceful vomiting, and the crunching, raspy sound heard on cardiac exam suggests mediastinal emphysema. A contrast esophagram is the best test to confirm this diagnosis. Upper endoscopy may not be feasible due to the risk of perforation, while ECG and D-dimer are not relevant for this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Boerhaave syndrome, which is a spontaneous esophageal rupture caused by the increased pressure from vomiting. A contrast esophagram can confirm the diagnosis by showing extravasation of contrast material from the esophagus. Upper endoscopy may also be used, but it carries a risk of perforation. ECG and measurement of D-dimer are not relevant to the diagnosis of Boerhaave syndrome.
